exercises.title: Verify Group Axioms
exercises.description: Verify whether the set $\mathbb{Z}$ with the operation $a \ast b = a + b + 1$ forms a group.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Check Closure
For all $a,b \in \mathbb{Z}$, $a \ast b = a + b + 1 \in \mathbb{Z}$
Thus, the operation is closed.

Step 2: Check Associativity
$(a \ast b) \ast c = (a + b + 1) \ast c = (a + b + 1) + c + 1 = a + b + c + 2$
$a \ast (b \ast c) = a \ast (b + c + 1) = a + (b + c + 1) + 1 = a + b + c + 2$
The operation is associative.

Step 3: Existence of Identity Element
Find $e \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $a \ast e = a$ for all $a \in \mathbb{Z}$
$a + e + 1 = a \Rightarrow e = -1$
$-1$ is the identity element.

Step 4: Existence of Inverses
For each $a \in \mathbb{Z}$, find $a^{-1}$ such that $a \ast a^{-1} = -1$
$a + a^{-1} + 1 = -1 \Rightarrow a^{-1} = -a - 2$
Every element has an inverse.

Step 5: Conclusion
$(\mathbb{Z}, \ast)$ satisfies all group axioms and is thus a group.

exercises.title: Subgroups and Normal Subgroups
exercises.description: Let $G = S_3$ be the symmetric group on 3 elements. Determine all subgroups of $G$ and check which of them are normal subgroups.
solutionSteps:
Step 2: Determine Subgroups
Trivial subgroups: $\{id\}$ and $S_3$
Cyclic subgroups:
$\langle (12) \rangle = \{id, (12)\}$
$\langle (13) \rangle = \{id, (13)\}$
$\langle (23) \rangle = \{id, (23)\}$
$\langle (123) \rangle = \{id, (123), (132)\}$

Step 3: Check for Normal Subgroups
$\{id\}$ and $S_3$ are always normal subgroups
$\langle (123) \rangle$ is a normal subgroup, as it has index 2
The 2-element subgroups are not normal subgroups, as they are not invariant under conjugation

Step 4: Summary
Subgroups: $\{id\}, S_3, \langle (12) \rangle, \langle (13) \rangle, \langle (23) \rangle, \langle (123) \rangle$
Normal subgroups: $\{id\}, S_3, \langle (123) \rangle$

exercises.title: Homomorphisms and Isomorphisms
exercises.description: Let $G = (\mathbb{R}^+, \cdot)$ be the multiplicative group of positive real numbers and $H = (\mathbb{R}, +)$ be the additive group of real numbers. Show that the map $\varphi: G \rightarrow H$ with $\varphi(x) = \ln(x)$ is a group isomorphism.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Check Homomorphism Property
$\varphi(xy) = \ln(xy) = \ln(x) + \ln(y) = \varphi(x) + \varphi(y)$
Thus, $\varphi$ is a homomorphism.

Step 2: Injectivity
Let $\varphi(x) = \varphi(y)$
$\ln(x) = \ln(y) \Rightarrow x = y$
Thus, $\varphi$ is injective.

Step 3: Surjectivity
For every $y \in \mathbb{R}$, there exists $x = e^y \in \mathbb{R}^+$ such that $\varphi(x) = y$
Thus, $\varphi$ is surjective.

Step 4: Conclusion
Since $\varphi$ is a bijective homomorphism, it is an isomorphism.

exercises.title: Quotient Groups
exercises.description: Let $G = \mathbb{Z} \times \mathbb{Z}$ and $H = \langle (2,0), (0,3) \rangle$. Determine the quotient group $G/H$ and show that it is isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_3$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Description of $H$
$H = \{(2k, 3l) \mid k,l \in \mathbb{Z}\}$

Step 3: Group Structure on $G/H$
$(a,b)+H + (c,d)+H = (a+c,b+d)+H$
The operation is well-defined.

Step 4: Isomorphism to $\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_3$
Define $\varphi: G/H \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_3$ by
$\varphi((a,b)+H) = (a \mod 2, b \mod 3)$
$\varphi$ is an isomorphism.

exercises.title: Sylow Theorems
exercises.description: Determine the number of 2-Sylow subgroups and 3-Sylow subgroups in $S_4$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Order of $S_4$
$|S_4| = 24 = 2^3 \cdot 3$

Step 2: Number of 2-Sylow Subgroups
By the 3rd Sylow Theorem:
$n_2 \equiv 1 \mod 2$ and $n_2$ divides 3
Possible values: $n_2 = 1$ or $n_2 = 3$
In fact, there are 3 2-Sylow subgroups (dihedral groups of order 8)

Step 3: Number of 3-Sylow Subgroups
By the 3rd Sylow Theorem:
$n_3 \equiv 1 \mod 3$ and $n_3$ divides 8
Possible values: $n_3 = 1$ or $n_3 = 4$
In fact, there are 4 3-Sylow subgroups (cyclic groups of order 3)

Step 4: Verification
The dihedral groups are:
$\langle (1234), (13) \rangle$
$\langle (1234), (12) \rangle$
$\langle (1234), (14) \rangle$
The 3-Sylow subgroups are:
$\langle (123) \rangle$
$\langle (124) \rangle$
$\langle (134) \rangle$
$\langle (234) \rangle$

exercises.title: Direct Products
exercises.description: Show that the group $\mathbb{Z}_6$ is isomorphic to the direct product $\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_3$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Define the Isomorphism
Define $\varphi: \mathbb{Z}_6 \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_3$ by
$\varphi([x]_6) = ([x]_2, [x]_3)$

Step 2: Well-Definedness
If $x \equiv y \mod 6$, then $x \equiv y \mod 2$ and $x \equiv y \mod 3$
Thus, $\varphi$ is well-defined.

Step 3: Homomorphism
$\varphi([x]_6 + [y]_6) = \varphi([x+y]_6) = ([x+y]_2, [x+y]_3) = ([x]_2 + [y]_2, [x]_3 + [y]_3) = \varphi([x]_6) + \varphi([y]_6)$

Step 4: Injectivity
$\varphi([x]_6) = \varphi([y]_6) \Rightarrow x \equiv y \mod 2$ and $x \equiv y \mod 3$
Since 2 and 3 are coprime, it follows that $x \equiv y \mod 6$

Step 5: Surjectivity
$|\mathbb{Z}_6| = |\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_3| = 6$
Since $\varphi$ is injective, it is also surjective.

Step 6: Conclusion
$\varphi$ is an isomorphism.

exercises.title: Automorphisms
exercises.description: Determine the automorphism group $\text{Aut}(\mathbb{Z}_8)$ of the cyclic group $\mathbb{Z}_8$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Generators of $\mathbb{Z}_8$
$\mathbb{Z}_8 = \langle 1 \rangle$
The generators are $\{1,3,5,7\}$

Step 2: Automorphisms
Every automorphism $\varphi$ is uniquely determined by the image of 1
$\varphi$ must map a generator to a generator

Step 3: Determine All Automorphisms
$\varphi_1: 1 \mapsto 1$
$\varphi_3: 1 \mapsto 3$
$\varphi_5: 1 \mapsto 5$
$\varphi_7: 1 \mapsto 7$

Step 4: Group Structure
$\text{Aut}(\mathbb{Z}_8) \cong \mathbb{Z}_8^\times = \{1,3,5,7\}$
The group is isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2$

Step 5: Verification
Multiplication table:
$\begin{array}{c|cccc}
\cdot & 1 & 3 & 5 & 7 \\\hline
1 & 1 & 3 & 5 & 7 \\
3 & 3 & 1 & 7 & 5 \\
5 & 5 & 7 & 1 & 3 \\
7 & 7 & 5 & 3 & 1
\end{array}$

exercises.title: Group Actions
exercises.description: Let $G = D_4$ be the dihedral group of order 8 (symmetry group of the square). Determine the orbits and stabilizers of the action of $G$ on the set of vertices of the square.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Elements of $D_4$
$D_4 = \{id, r, r^2, r^3, s, sr, sr^2, sr^3\}$
where $r$ is a 90Â° rotation and $s$ is a reflection

Step 2: Orbits
The set of vertices is $X = \{1,2,3,4\}$
There is only one orbit, as any vertex can be mapped to any other vertex

Step 3: Stabilizers
$G_1 = \{id, s\}$
$G_2 = \{id, sr\}$
$G_3 = \{id, sr^2\}$
$G_4 = \{id, sr^3\}$

Step 4: Orbit-Stabilizer Theorem
$|G| = |G_x| \cdot |Gx|$ for each $x \in X$
$8 = 2 \cdot 4$

Step 5: Interpretation
The action is transitive (one orbit)
The stabilizers are the reflections that fix the respective vertex

exercises.title: Finite Abelian Groups
exercises.description: Determine all abelian groups of order 36 up to isomorphism.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Prime Factorization
$36 = 2^2 \cdot 3^2$

Step 2: Possible Decompositions
By the Fundamental Theorem of Finite Abelian Groups:
$\mathbb{Z}_4 \times \mathbb{Z}_9$
$\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_9$
$\mathbb{Z}_4 \times \mathbb{Z}_3 \times \mathbb{Z}_3$
$\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_3 \times \mathbb{Z}_3$

Step 3: Verify Orders
All groups have order 36
No two of the groups are isomorphic

Step 4: Elementary Divisors
$\mathbb{Z}_4 \times \mathbb{Z}_9$: $(4,9)$
$\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_9$: $(2,2,9)$
$\mathbb{Z}_4 \times \mathbb{Z}_3 \times \mathbb{Z}_3$: $(4,3,3)$
$\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_3 \times \mathbb{Z}_3$: $(2,2,3,3)$

exercises.title: Group Extensions
exercises.description: Show that the quaternion group $Q_8$ is a central extension of $\mathbb{Z}_2$ by $\mathbb{Z}_4$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Definition of $Q_8$
$Q_8 = \{\pm 1, \pm i, \pm j, \pm k\}$
with $i^2 = j^2 = k^2 = -1$, $ij = k$, $jk = i$, $ki = j$

Step 2: Center
$Z(Q_8) = \{\pm 1\} \cong \mathbb{Z}_2$

Step 3: Quotient Group
$Q_8/Z(Q_8) \cong \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2$

Step 4: Extension
The short exact sequence
$1 \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_2 \rightarrow Q_8 \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \rightarrow 1$
is a central extension

Step 5: Verification
The extension is non-trivial, as $Q_8$ is not isomorphic to $\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2$

exercises.title: Simple Group Axioms
exercises.description: Verify whether the set $\{1, -1\}$ with ordinary multiplication forms a group.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Check Closure
$1 \cdot 1 = 1 \in \{1, -1\}$
$1 \cdot (-1) = -1 \in \{1, -1\}$
$-1 \cdot 1 = -1 \in \{1, -1\}$
$-1 \cdot (-1) = 1 \in \{1, -1\}$
The operation is closed.

Step 2: Associativity
Multiplication is associative.

Step 3: Identity Element
$1$ is the identity element.

Step 4: Inverses
$1^{-1} = 1$
$(-1)^{-1} = -1$
Every element has an inverse.

Step 5: Conclusion
$(\{1, -1\}, \cdot)$ is a group.

exercises.title: Subgroups
exercises.description: Determine all subgroups of $\mathbb{Z}_6$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Elements of $\mathbb{Z}_6$
$\mathbb{Z}_6 = \{0,1,2,3,4,5\}$

Step 2: Trivial Subgroups
$\{0\}$ and $\mathbb{Z}_6$ are subgroups

Step 3: Cyclic Subgroups
$\langle 1 \rangle = \mathbb{Z}_6$
$\langle 2 \rangle = \{0,2,4\}$
$\langle 3 \rangle = \{0,3\}$
$\langle 4 \rangle = \{0,2,4\}$
$\langle 5 \rangle = \mathbb{Z}_6$

Step 4: Summary
Subgroups: $\{0\}, \{0,3\}, \{0,2,4\}, \mathbb{Z}_6$

exercises.title: Order of Elements
exercises.description: Determine the order of each element in $\mathbb{Z}_8$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Elements of $\mathbb{Z}_8$
$\mathbb{Z}_8 = \{0,1,2,3,4,5,6,7\}$

exercises.title: Cyclic Groups
exercises.description: Show that $\mathbb{Z}_4$ is a cyclic group and determine all generators.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Elements of $\mathbb{Z}_4$
$\mathbb{Z}_4 = \{0,1,2,3\}$

Step 2: Generators
$\langle 1 \rangle = \{0,1,2,3\} = \mathbb{Z}_4$
$\langle 3 \rangle = \{0,3,2,1\} = \mathbb{Z}_4$

Step 3: Conclusion
$\mathbb{Z}_4$ is cyclic with generators 1 and 3

exercises.title: Direct Products
exercises.description: Determine the order of each element in $\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_3$.

exercises.title: Homomorphisms
exercises.description: Show that the map $\varphi: \mathbb{Z}_6 \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_6$ with $\varphi(x) = 2x$ is a group homomorphism.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Homomorphism Property
$\varphi(x + y) = 2(x + y) = 2x + 2y = \varphi(x) + \varphi(y)$

Step 2: Image
$\text{im}(\varphi) = \{0,2,4\}$

Step 3: Kernel
$\ker(\varphi) = \{0,3\}$

exercises.title: Normal Subgroups
exercises.description: Show that $\{0,3\}$ is a normal subgroup in $\mathbb{Z}_6$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Subgroup
$\{0,3\}$ is a subgroup of $\mathbb{Z}_6$

Step 2: Normal Subgroup
For all $g \in \mathbb{Z}_6$ and $h \in \{0,3\}$:
$g + h - g = h \in \{0,3\}$
Thus, $\{0,3\}$ is a normal subgroup

exercises.title: Quotient Groups
exercises.description: Determine the quotient group $\mathbb{Z}_6/\{0,3\}$.
solutionSteps:
Step 2: Group Structure
$\mathbb{Z}_6/\{0,3\} \cong \mathbb{Z}_3$

exercises.title: Group Actions
exercises.description: Let $G = \mathbb{Z}_4$ and $X = \{1,2,3,4\}$. Define the action $g \cdot x = x + g \mod 4$. Determine the orbits and stabilizers.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Orbits
$G \cdot 1 = \{1,2,3,4\}$
There is only one orbit, as the action is transitive

Step 3: Orbit-Stabilizer Theorem
$|G| = |G_x| \cdot |Gx|$
$4 = 1 \cdot 4$

exercises.title: Sylow Subgroups
exercises.description: Determine the number of 2-Sylow subgroups in $\mathbb{Z}_{12}$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Order
$|\mathbb{Z}_{12}| = 12 = 2^2 \cdot 3$

Step 2: 2-Sylow Subgroups
By the 3rd Sylow Theorem:
$n_2 \equiv 1 \mod 2$ and $n_2$ divides 3
Thus, $n_2 = 1$

Step 3: Verification
The only 2-Sylow subgroup is $\{0,3,6,9\}$

exercises.title: Automorphisms
exercises.description: Determine the automorphism group $\text{Aut}(\mathbb{Z}_5)$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Generators
$\mathbb{Z}_5 = \langle 1 \rangle$
The generators are $\{1,2,3,4\}$

Step 2: Automorphisms
Every automorphism $\varphi$ is uniquely determined by the image of 1
$\varphi$ must map a generator to a generator

Step 3: Determine All Automorphisms
$\varphi_1: 1 \mapsto 1$
$\varphi_2: 1 \mapsto 2$
$\varphi_3: 1 \mapsto 3$
$\varphi_4: 1 \mapsto 4$

Step 4: Group Structure
$\text{Aut}(\mathbb{Z}_5) \cong \mathbb{Z}_5^\times = \{1,2,3,4\}$
The group is cyclic of order 4

exercises.title: Group Extensions
exercises.description: Show that $\mathbb{Z}_4$ is a central extension of $\mathbb{Z}_2$ by $\mathbb{Z}_2$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Center
$Z(\mathbb{Z}_4) = \{0,2\} \cong \mathbb{Z}_2$

Step 2: Quotient Group
$\mathbb{Z}_4/Z(\mathbb{Z}_4) \cong \mathbb{Z}_2$

Step 3: Extension
The short exact sequence
$1 \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_2 \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_4 \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_2 \rightarrow 1$
is a central extension

exercises.title: Finite Abelian Groups
exercises.description: Determine all abelian groups of order 8 up to isomorphism.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Prime Factorization
$8 = 2^3$

Step 2: Possible Decompositions
$\mathbb{Z}_8$
$\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_4$
$\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2$

Step 3: Verification
All groups have order 8
No two of the groups are isomorphic

exercises.title: Group Actions on Sets
exercises.description: Let $G = \mathbb{Z}_4$ and $X = \{1,2,3,4\}$. Define the action $g \cdot x = x + g \mod 4$. Determine the number of fixed points of each element of $G$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Elements of $G$
$G = \{0,1,2,3\}$

Step 2: Fixed Points
$0$ has 4 fixed points
$1$ has 0 fixed points
$2$ has 0 fixed points
$3$ has 0 fixed points

Step 3: Orbit-Stabilizer Theorem
$|X| = \frac{1}{|G|} \sum_{g \in G} |\text{Fix}(g)|$
$4 = \frac{1}{4}(4 + 0 + 0 + 0)$

exercises.title: Complex Group Actions
exercises.description: Let $G = S_4$ be the symmetric group on 4 elements. Determine the number of orbits of the action of $G$ on the set of 2-element subsets of $\{1,2,3,4\}$.
solutionSteps:
Step 2: Orbits
There is only one orbit, as any 2-element subset can be mapped to any other

Step 4: Orbit-Stabilizer Theorem
$|G| = |G_x| \cdot |Gx|$
$24 = 4 \cdot 6$

exercises.title: Sylow Theorems and Normal Subgroups
exercises.description: Show that every group of order 15 has a normal subgroup of order 3 and a normal subgroup of order 5.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Sylow Subgroups
$|G| = 15 = 3 \cdot 5$
$n_3 \equiv 1 \mod 3$ and $n_3$ divides 5
$n_5 \equiv 1 \mod 5$ and $n_5$ divides 3$

Step 2: Number of Sylow Subgroups
$n_3 = 1$
$n_5 = 1$

Step 3: Normal Subgroups
The unique 3-Sylow subgroup is a normal subgroup
The unique 5-Sylow subgroup is a normal subgroup

Step 4: Conclusion
$G$ has normal subgroups of orders 3 and 5

exercises.title: Complex Automorphisms
exercises.description: Determine the automorphism group $\text{Aut}(\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_4)$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Generators
$\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_4 = \langle (1,0), (0,1) \rangle$

Step 2: Automorphisms
Every automorphism $\varphi$ is determined by the images of $(1,0)$ and $(0,1)$
$\varphi(1,0)$ must have order 2
$\varphi(0,1)$ must have order 4

Step 3: Determine All Automorphisms
$\varphi(1,0) \in \{(1,0), (1,2)\}$
$\varphi(0,1) \in \{(0,1), (0,3)\}$

Step 4: Group Structure
$\text{Aut}(\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_4) \cong D_4$

exercises.title: Complex Group Extensions
exercises.description: Show that the dihedral group $D_4$ is a non-trivial extension of $\mathbb{Z}_2$ by $\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Center
$Z(D_4) = \{1, r^2\} \cong \mathbb{Z}_2$

Step 2: Quotient Group
$D_4/Z(D_4) \cong \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2$

Step 3: Extension
The short exact sequence
$1 \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_2 \rightarrow D_4 \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \rightarrow 1$
is a non-trivial extension

Step 4: Verification
The extension is non-trivial, as $D_4$ is not abelian

exercises.title: Complex Finite Abelian Groups
exercises.description: Determine all abelian groups of order 72 up to isomorphism.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Prime Factorization
$72 = 2^3 \cdot 3^2$

Step 2: Possible Decompositions
$\mathbb{Z}_8 \times \mathbb{Z}_9$
$\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_4 \times \mathbb{Z}_9$
$\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_9$
$\mathbb{Z}_8 \times \mathbb{Z}_3 \times \mathbb{Z}_3$
$\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_4 \times \mathbb{Z}_3 \times \mathbb{Z}_3$
$\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_3 \times \mathbb{Z}_3$

Step 3: Verification
All groups have order 72
No two of the groups are isomorphic

exercises.title: Complex Group Actions on Polynomials
exercises.description: Let $G = S_3$ be the symmetric group on 3 elements. Determine the number of orbits of the action of $G$ on the set of polynomials of degree 2 over $\mathbb{F}_2$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Polynomials
$X = \{x^2, x^2 + 1, x^2 + x, x^2 + x + 1\}$

Step 4: Orbit-Stabilizer Theorem
$|G| = |G_x| \cdot |Gx|$
$6 = 6 \cdot 1$ for $x^2$ and $x^2 + 1$
$6 = 2 \cdot 3$ for $x^2 + x$

exercises.title: Complex Sylow Theorems
exercises.description: Show that every group of order 30 has a normal subgroup of order 15.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Sylow Subgroups
$|G| = 30 = 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 5$
$n_3 \equiv 1 \mod 3$ and $n_3$ divides 10
$n_5 \equiv 1 \mod 5$ and $n_5$ divides 6$

Step 2: Number of Sylow Subgroups
$n_3 = 1$ or $n_3 = 10$
$n_5 = 1$ or $n_5 = 6$

Step 3: Analysis
If $n_3 = 10$ and $n_5 = 6$, then $G$ has at least 20 elements of order 3 and 24 elements of order 5, which is impossible

Step 4: Conclusion
$n_3 = 1$ or $n_5 = 1$
The corresponding Sylow subgroup is a normal subgroup
The product of the normal subgroups is a normal subgroup of order 15

exercises.title: Complex Automorphisms and Endomorphisms
exercises.description: Determine the automorphism group $\text{Aut}(\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2)$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Vector Space Structure
$\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2$ is a 3-dimensional vector space over $\mathbb{Z}_2$

Step 2: Automorphisms
The automorphisms correspond to the invertible 3x3 matrices over $\mathbb{Z}_2$

Step 3: Number of Automorphisms
$|\text{Aut}(\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2)| = |GL_3(\mathbb{Z}_2)| = 168$

Step 4: Group Structure
$\text{Aut}(\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2) \cong GL_3(\mathbb{Z}_2)$

exercises.title: Complex Group Extensions and Cohomology
exercises.description: Show that the quaternion group $Q_8$ is a non-trivial extension of $\mathbb{Z}_2$ by $\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2$ and determine the associated element in $H^2(\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2, \mathbb{Z}_2)$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: Center
$Z(Q_8) = \{\pm 1\} \cong \mathbb{Z}_2$

Step 2: Quotient Group
$Q_8/Z(Q_8) \cong \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2$

Step 3: Extension
The short exact sequence
$1 \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_2 \rightarrow Q_8 \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2 \rightarrow 1$
is a non-trivial extension

Step 4: Cohomology
The associated element in $H^2(\mathbb{Z}_2 \times \mathbb{Z}_2, \mathbb{Z}_2)$ is non-trivial

exercises.title: Complex Group Actions on Vector Spaces
exercises.description: Let $G = GL_2(\mathbb{F}_2)$ be the general linear group over $\mathbb{F}_2$. Determine the number of orbits of the action of $G$ on the set of 1-dimensional subspaces of $\mathbb{F}_2^2$.
solutionSteps:
Step 1: 1-Dimensional Subspaces
$X = \{\langle (1,0) \rangle, \langle (0,1) \rangle, \langle (1,1) \rangle\}$

Step 2: Orbits
There is only one orbit, as $G$ acts transitively on $X$

Step 3: Stabilizer
$G_{\langle (1,0) \rangle} = \{\begin{pmatrix} 1 & a \\ 0 & b \end{pmatrix} \mid a \in \mathbb{F}_2, b \in \mathbb{F}_2^\times\}$
$|G_{\langle (1,0) \rangle}| = 2$

Step 4: Orbit-Stabilizer Theorem
$|G| = |G_x| \cdot |Gx|$
$6 = 2 \cdot 3$
